G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 209C, § 20 and G.L. c. 208, § 28.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 209C, § 20 and G.L. c. 208, § 28.

**Hunter v. Rose**, 463 Mass. 488, 494 (.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, this Court has the authority to modify a prior custody judgment upon a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances and where modification is in the best interests of the child. See G.L. c. 208, § 28; **Hunter v. Rose**, 463 Mass. 488, 494 (2012).
**Hunter v. Rose**, 463 Mass. 488, 494 (.support_reasoning: The excerpted portion of Hunter v. Rose discusses recognition of a California registered domestic partnership, determination of legal parentage, and an initial custody determination based on the best interests of the child. It does not address the court’s authority to *modify* a prior custody judgment, nor does it refer to the ‘material and substantial change in circumstances’ standard under G.L. c. 208, § 28. The proposition concerns modification of an existing custody order; Hunter deals with an original custody award and thus does not provide authority for the claimed modification standard.
**Hunter v. Rose**, 463 Mass. 488, 494 (.relevant_excerpt: “Parents have an equal right to custody of their children. See Commonwealth v. Beals, 405 Mass. 550, 554 (1989). ‘In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry [is] … what is “best for the child”…. ’ Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 840 (2003). ‘The determination of which parent will promote a child’s best interests rests within the discretion of the judge … [whose] findings … “must stand unless they are plainly wrong.”’ Id. at 845, quoting Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182, 191 (1998).”

**Mason v. Coleman**, 447 Mass. 177, 183.proposition: A material change in circumstances can include the physical or mental health of a parent that impacts their ability to ensure the child’s welfare. See **Mason v. Coleman**, 447 Mass. 177, 183-84 (2006).
**Mason v. Coleman**, 447 Mass. 177, 183.support_reasoning: The opinion in Mason v. Coleman concerns standards for removal of children from the Commonwealth in a joint physical custody situation and how to apply a best-interests analysis to relocation. It does not discuss modification based on a material change in circumstances, nor does it address the physical or mental health of a parent as a change in circumstances affecting ability to ensure a child’s welfare. The cited pages (183-84) focus on the best-interests standard and relocation impacts, not parental health conditions or material-change doctrine.
**Mason v. Coleman**, 447 Mass. 177, 183.relevant_excerpt: “‘The words “upon cause shown” mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child.’ Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 711 (1985), citing Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 (1976). … ‘[T]he best interests of the child standard is one grounded in the particular needs and circumstances of the individual child in question.’ Adoption of Vito, 431 Mass. 550, 566 (2000).”

**Custody of Calyre**, 433 Mass. 55, 66-.proposition: The Court must prioritize the best interests of the child, which includes considering the child’s safety, emotional well-being, and need for stability and continuity. See **Custody of Calyre**, 433 Mass. 55, 66-67 (2000); **Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas**, 395 Mass. 704, 711 (1985).
**Custody of Calyre**, 433 Mass. 55, 66-.support_reasoning: This opinion is a criminal homicide appeal (Commonwealth v. Roberts), not the Custody of Calyre decision and does not address child custody, best interests of the child, or related factors such as safety, emotional well‑being, or stability. The text concerns evidentiary rulings, prosecutorial argument, jury instructions, and postverdict motions in a murder case. It therefore does not support the cited proposition about prioritizing the best interests of the child.
**Custody of Calyre**, 433 Mass. 55, 66-.relevant_excerpt: There is no discussion anywhere in this opinion of child custody, best interests of the child, or related family-law principles; the case is entirely about a murder conviction and associated procedural and evidentiary issues.

**Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas**, 395 Mas.proposition: The Court must prioritize the best interests of the child, which includes considering the child’s safety, emotional well-being, and need for stability and continuity. See **Custody of Calyre**, 433 Mass. 55, 66-67 (2000); **Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas**, 395 Mass. 704, 711 (1985).
**Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas**, 395 Mas.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly interprets the removal statute’s “upon cause shown” language to mean that removal must be in the best interests of the child and then explains how those best interests are to be evaluated. In doing so, the Court identifies factors including the effect on the child’s quality of life, and the impact on the child’s emotional, physical, and developmental needs, thereby supporting a broad, best‑interests focus that includes safety, emotional well‑being, and stability/continuity.
**Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas**, 395 Mas.relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that… ‘upon cause shown’ [means] only that removal must be in the best interests of the child… and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined.… An evaluation of the best interests of the child requires attention to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change … and the extent to which moving or not moving will affect the emotional, physical, or developmental needs of the child.”

**Callahan v. Callahan**, 85 Mass. App..proposition: The Defendant’s progressive neurological condition renders him unable to safely manage a 50/50 physical custody arrangement, creating a material and substantial change in circumstances meeting the threshold for modification under Massachusetts law. See **Callahan v. Callahan**, 85 Mass. App. Ct. 369, 376 (2014); **Hughes v. McGrath**, 94 Mass. App. Ct. 221, 224 (2018).
**Callahan v. Callahan**, 85 Mass. App..support_reasoning: Callahan is a c. 209A restraining order case concerning extension of an abuse prevention order where the defendant is incarcerated. It does not address physical custody, parenting time, parental capacity, or what constitutes a material and substantial change in circumstances for modification of a custody judgment under Massachusetts domestic relations law. Using Callahan to support a proposition about a parent’s progressive neurological condition and modification of a 50/50 custody arrangement misstates the scope and subject of the decision.
**Callahan v. Callahan**, 85 Mass. App..relevant_excerpt: “At issue is whether a Probate and Family Court judge abused his discretion in extending (and refusing to modify or terminate) an abuse prevention order issued under G. L. c. 209A when the subject of that order was also serving a prison sentence for crimes of violence against the plaintiff who obtained the order.… Whether seeking an initial abuse prevention order under G. L. c. 209A or a later extension, the burden is on the plaintiff to establish facts justifying issuance, or continuance, by a preponderance of the evidence.”

**Hughes v. McGrath**, 94 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: The Defendant’s progressive neurological condition renders him unable to safely manage a 50/50 physical custody arrangement, creating a material and substantial change in circumstances meeting the threshold for modification under Massachusetts law. See **Callahan v. Callahan**, 85 Mass. App. Ct. 369, 376 (2014); **Hughes v. McGrath**, 94 Mass. App. Ct. 221, 224 (2018).

**Pettinella v. Pettinella**, 41 Mass. A.proposition: Additionally, the current arrangement impermissibly places Samantha in circumstances where her safety and well-being are compromised, necessitating a modification of custody for her best interests, consistent with **Pettinella v. Pettinella**, 41 Mass. App. Ct. 276 (1996) and **Schechter v. Schechter**, 88 Mass. App. Ct. 239, 245 (2015).
**Pettinella v. Pettinella**, 41 Mass. A.case_name: G.M. Abodeely Insurance Agency, Inc. v. Commerce Insurance
**Pettinella v. Pettinella**, 41 Mass. A.support_reasoning: This opinion is a commercial contract/insurance agency termination case and does not concern child custody, best interests of a child, or circumstances compromising a child’s safety and well-being. It analyzes whether an insurance agency contract was terminable at will and what constitutes a material breach, not standards for modifying custody. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the proposition about modifying custody based on a child’s compromised safety and best interests.
**Pettinella v. Pettinella**, 41 Mass. A.relevant_excerpt: “The principal issue on Commerce’s appeal is whether it could cancel the agency contract ‘at will’ or whether, as the jury was instructed, a material breach was required before Commerce could cancel the contract without liability. We affirm the judgment.”

**Schechter v. Schechter**, 88 Mass. App.proposition: Additionally, the current arrangement impermissibly places Samantha in circumstances where her safety and well-being are compromised, necessitating a modification of custody for her best interests, consistent with **Pettinella v. Pettinella**, 41 Mass. App. Ct. 276 (1996) and **Schechter v. Schechter**, 88 Mass. App. Ct. 239, 245 (2015).
**Schechter v. Schechter**, 88 Mass. App.support_reasoning: The proposition asserts that circumstances compromising a child’s safety and well‑being can warrant modifying custody in the child’s best interests. Schechter squarely supports that principle: the Appeals Court affirms an award of sole legal and physical custody to the mother and a one‑year cessation of all contact between father and child based on findings of domestic abuse and emotional harm, explicitly tying custody and visitation decisions to the child’s safety and best interests under G. L. c. 208, §§ 31 and 31A and c. 209A § 3(d). Thus it is appropriate authority for arguing that an unsafe arrangement necessitates custody modification for the child’s welfare.
**Schechter v. Schechter**, 88 Mass. App.relevant_excerpt: “In making a decision about legal or physical custody, a judge ‘shall consider whether or not the child’s present or past living conditions adversely affect his physical, mental, moral or emotional health.’ G. L. c. 208, § 31… Furthermore, in such cases the judge ‘shall consider evidence of past or present abuse toward a parent or child as a factor contrary to the best interest of the child.’ G. L. c. 208, § 31A… [T]he decision to suspend the father’s visitation rights with the child was based on the exercise of a sound discretion.”
